musicalLanguage.description: B.B. King's signature song, recorded in 1969 with a string section that transformed blues forever. The minor key gives it a haunting, melancholy quality unlike standard major-key blues. The melody is sparse and vocal — every note is chosen with the economy of a master storyteller.
musicalLanguage.structure: Minor blues form (Bm-Em-F#7). This excerpt: first 8 bars
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: Bm — the stark minor opening. Sparse melody over a simple bass.
Bar 3-4: Bm continues — the space between notes IS the emotion
Bar 5-6: Em — the iv chord deepens the sadness
Bar 7-8: Bm — return to the tonic with a melodic sigh
teachingGoals: Minor blues form — different from standard major 12-bar
Economy of notes — saying more with less, B.B. King style
Minor key voicings and the natural minor scale
styleTips: Less is more — B.B. King was the master of one perfect note
Let notes sustain and decay naturally — use the pedal
The rests are emotional — they are where the listener feels the weight

measures.teachingNote: Bm — the melody enters simply. D-F#-D outlines the minor triad. Spare and powerful.
Bm — the melody descends to the root and stops. The silence speaks.
Bm — melody climbs stepwise. A-B-D-E from the B natural minor scale.
Bm — settling back down. Two half notes, unhurried. No rush.
Em — the iv chord. Melody descends through Em chord tones. The sadness deepens.
Em — rest after E5. Let the minor quality hang in the air.
Bm — melody sighs downward: D-C#-B. The C# adds a dorian color.
Bm — a small upward gesture (A to B) before resting. Breath before the next phrase.
